captions.text:
MATT FARAH: 30 seconds ago you
clicked on a link that said,
SDHQ Ecoboost Raptor.
And you got very excited.

And yet here I am, in a turret
on top of an armored vehicle,

holding a .50 caliber
sniper rifle.

Now at this point, you're
probably asking yourself, why

am I in a turret, holding a
.50 caliber sniper rifle.

The answer of course, one
simple word, Arizona.

Today we are driving the
Ecoboost Raptor,
right here on TUNED.

This is what a pickup truck is
suppose to be, the exact

opposite of the hilariously
useless excuses for sports
trucks we've seen the past.

The Ford Lightning, GMC Syclone,
and Dodge SRT Ram.

No other truck comes this
prepared to play in the dirt.

No other truck can show up at
the dunes, the trails, Home

Depot, or Beverly Hills
valet equally ready
for the task at hand.

And for our purposes, no other
truck would make a better
camera vehicle.
It's an all around win.

But considering how sorted the
truck comes from the factory,

we were always surprised at the
lack of engine choices.

RYAN MARSELIS: Once Ford came
out with the new build list

for the Raptor for 2012, we
noticed that the Ecoboost
wasn't an option.

There was rumors that
it would be.

Once we saw that, we knew
we had to build one.

So last October we started with
a new 2012 F150 extra cab

that come with a 6
and 1/2 foot bed.

And we did a frame swap,
and a suspension swap,
bed, things like that.

And built the first Ecoboost
Raptor and debuted it
at SEMA last year.

It'll definitely outperform a
Stock 6.2 Raptor, and even a

Raptor that has chip intake
and exhaust done to it.
It's definitely a mover.

MATT FARAH: I am envious
to say the least.

I am really digging this
truck right now.

And the 40 mile transit from
SDHQ's shop to where we're at

right now, I have averaged
16.8 miles per gallon,

compared to 11 and 1/2 in the
other Raptor that we're using

as a camera car, or what I've
been known to get in my
personal Raptor.

Doing that math for the 34,000
miles I've put on my Raptor

would save me, $1,350
a year in gas.

I would have spent $8,000 total
on gas over the life of

my truck, versus the $12,000
I've actually spent.
So there's that.

Then there's the power, with the
intake, the exhaust, and

the tune on the Ecoboost engine,
you're making a little

over 400 horsepower, probably
about 410 with the crank, but,
like, 500 pounds of torque.

And with the turbos, it
comes on really early.

This thing's scoots right
off the line.

And it makes a really
cool sound.
[ENGINE REVVING]
MATT FARAH: It goes.
This thing is quick.

It's definitely quicker then
my truck, no question.

I might even argue that this
thing makes more than 410

horsepower, could be closer
to about 450.
But it's pretty effortless.

I'm not surprised the Eco
Raptor is faster than my

truck, since it's lighter
and more powerful.

But these are abusive conditions
for testing.

And the most amazing thing is
that, for a modified truck, it

feels as solid as if it just
left the factory floor.

There's no squeaks, no rattles,
and the fit in finish
is flawless.

And that's because this thing
reads like a parts list from
the SDHQ catalog.

RYAN MARSELIS: It has our front
LED bumper, it has our
upgraded skip plates.

Up front it has, Icon coil-over
suspensions, their
upper control arms.

Out back we have Deaver rear
springs, we have our bump stop
kit in the rear.

We're also running some Icon 3
inch diameter shocks out back.

Running a custom rear bumper
that we built with a couple
spare tires in it.

Besides that, it has
a couple bolt-ons.

As far as a performance goes,
it has an AFE intake kit, it

has a Superchips tuner and it
has an AFE cat back exhaust.

As far as adding on more
horsepower and torque and
power, it's there.

You have plenty of tuners that
are available for it.

There's companies making
aftermarket
inner coolers for it.

The power gains are there, the
stock Ecoboost is great.

But just with adding the Chip
intake and exhaust, you're

getting another 50 horses, 80-90
foot pounds of torque,

which are huge gains
for a gas motor.

MATT FARAH: Just cruising
right now at about 45.
Ride's nice.

Rained yesterday, so we
get some mud going on.

Probably the most interesting
thing about this truck, is

that it's not a Raptor with
an Ecoboost engine swap.

It's actually an Ecoboost
truck, with a Raptor
frame and body swap.

There's a lot more involved
to that than you think.

Because they have to switch
frames, they have to put a
shorter bed.

The entire front and rear
clip are different.

And then you've got all the
Raptor parts plus the

aftermarket stuff
they put on it.

And that seems silly, you
might think why not
just swap the motor.

But the Ecoboost engine from
the factory cost $17,000.

If you do out the math which
they've done, it is actually

more economically feasible to
swap the body and frame, then
to swap the engine.

The bad news of course is that
you don't get the Raptor seats

or steering wheel,
which I like.
But, such is life.

I'm still in two wheel drive
right now, I haven't even
locked the diff.
Truck is good.

This suspension is
really nice.

Unfortunately to get this
conversion from SDHQ, it is
kind of expensive.

Sarina the owner of this
truck, has over $80,000
dollars into it.

Whoa, there we go, a little
washes, yeah.

I am absolutely loving the
steering flow of this thing.

I've got a little more
wide open space here.
And it start's to rain.

Go a little faster and
see what happens.

Whoa a tire all the
way out here.
Take it up to about 50.

Riding really smooth,
really nice.
Whoa, yes.

This does require a little bit
of attention, so if I'm
talking less, that is why.

I don't have any idea where I'm
going, it doesn't really

matter because I'm
in a Raptor.
How about this way.
Whoa.

Wow look at that Jeep coming
down that hill in reverse,
well done sir.

The only real downside is that
without a real original Raptor

drive line, you can't lock the
differential unless you're in

4x4 mode, making drifting
more difficult.

The stock Raptors two wheel
drive locking diff, makes for
excellent roof protection.

This truck is not only faster,
but it's more nimble, it's
lighter, it's more efficient.

And with the upgraded
suspension, it's better off
road than my truck.

And what happens is I'm annoyed,
because they have

done such a good job
with their truck.

And now I have to go home
and live with mine.

So kudos to SDHQ for building
a bad-ass truck.

And look for Craigslist Los
Angeles to see an orange 2010
Raptor up there, pretty soon.

I'm Matt Farah, you've
been watching TUNED.

comments.text:
My F-150 with the 5.0 sounds like is has way more balls, has 385 HP with 
slight mods and gets 16.1 overall MPG right now. 

That is a sweet truck, don't get me wrong, but I can never leave the true 
roar of a big V8. I bought the truck knowing I am going to spend coin on 
fuel, I am ok with that, ﻿
comments.author: Sam Griswold

comments.text:
+Sam Griswold Thankyou sir! While i don't have a raptor (sierra owner here) 
i share the same sentiment. I plan on a supercharger and Rogue Racing long 
travel suspension on my 14 Sierra before it's all said and done. I have no 
desire or want for a v6. And specs be damned why don't we play fair ball 
and force induce a V8 then see which is putting out better specs. Don't get 
me wrong i get it people want to have their cake and eat it to. I.E. Drive 
a raptor with 35s and get 16mpg. That might be for some, but most self 
respecting truck owners that buy these trucks to use them as intended would 
never sacrifice that v8 roar for turboed v6 and automated sound.

All that said cylinder deactivation is netting me 18-20 here in the delta 
17 in the hills. Now those are just leveled. Still have headers, tune, 
tires, wheels, exhaust, and an intake to go though. Then later on long 
travel, fiberglass fenders, and supercharger.

comments.author: Richard Burns

comments.text:
+Jason Davis As I've mentioned a few times private property, or not it 
doesn't matter the laws still apply. Also, the laws regarding parking in 
handicapped spaces still apply after business hours. Sure the chances of 
those spaces being used might be slim, but they are still handicapped 
parking spaces and if a Police Officer wanted to be a real stickler they 
could issue someone a citation for illegally parking in one. As for why I 
decided to go out of my way to mention this in a Raptor video, it's because 
as a disabled driver who uses a wheelchair I need access to handicapped 
parking and it gets annoying to find business owners illegally parking in 
handicapped spaces. It tends to piss me off when I pull into the parking 
lot and have to stop in the parking lot, then call the establishment that I 
want to do business with and ask them to move their illegally parked 
vehicle so I can park my vehicle in that space so I can come into their 
establishment and do business with them. Sometimes when that happens I just 
take my business elsewhere.
comments.author: Tat2Dragons

comments.text:
+Richard Burns Wrong, whether it's on private property, or not as soon as a 
parking spot gets marked as an official handicapped parking space, the 
owner of that property has to abide by the same laws regarding handicapped 
parking as everyone else. Oh and you calling me a prick, grow up, name 
calling is for little kids.
comments.author: Tat2Dragons

comments.author: BMW Guy

comments.text:
Hmmm interesting, That makes me wonder how it has such a strong power 
curve, I assumed it was sequential turbos. I would sort of like to look 
into the tech behind it, but don't feel like it. I was aware it had some 
sort of intercooler (no way it could make power like that without one), but 
as I am familiar with the way the motor runs (a friend of mine has a fleet 
of ecoboost pickups) I was already aware the intercooler was not enough for 
a sustained heavy workload. This is a truck that can burn its top end up 
within 75000 miles of pushed (even if taken care of), which is unacceptable 
by my standards of durability. I actually hadn't meant for that to be for 
you anyway, I meant for it to be for the other guy who thought for some 
reason that a v6 could never touch a v8 lol. I personally don't have too 
much interest in what Ford does, so my opinion of them is probably unfairly 
low when I talk about them:)
comments.author: Zachary Strain

comments.text:
+Zachary Strain You got a few things wrong... first, I was talking about 
the entire RPM range, a single turbo motor will outperform an N/A one 
across its entire RPM range. Second, the V6 ecoboost is twin turbo, both 
turbos are identical in size, shape, spool times, etc. They're running in 
parallel, one on each side of the V. What you described is known as 
sequential turbos, not twin turbos, and is not applicable to this 
discussion. Even in its stock form the ecoboost has a sizable intercooler 
for the engine size and the truck can accommodate a much, much larger one 
that any serious tower can and would upgrade to. FYI, I work with 
turbocharged cars all day, every day and I wouldn't hesitate to throw a 
trailer behind an ecoboost V6. I would upgrade some things if I was going 
to do is every day, but if I was towing a heavy load every day I'd have a 
diesel. As far as durability of the engines themselves, the V6 is actually 
tougher than the V8 is many notable ways, as it's a decreased displacement 
N/A engine with stronger internal components. But, to be honest, neither 
the ecoboost V6 or the coyote V8 has been around long enough to be able to 
judge which is more durable in the long term... but since they're both 
incredibly complex with many, many unnecessary electronic components to 
fail, I doubt there will be much difference in the long, long term, as all 
modern vehicles are essentially designed to be disposable.
comments.author: deimosian

comments.text:
+deimosian I feel inclined to post something here, as I have a bit of 
knowledge on this topic (though this thread is old). When you think of a 
turbocharged engine only producing high peak torque, and low power at other 
points in its power band, you are thinking of an engine with a single 
turbocharger. Turbos have a rpm area where they work best, and typically 
they are tuned to only kick in at high rpm so you only get the power when 
you are pushing the car hard enough to rev it up. This is not the case for 
many twin-turbo configurations, and the ecoboost is no exception. The 
ecoboost has a smaller turbo that spools up quickly to deliver boost at low 
rpm, and as the engine revs up and the power delivery offered solely by the 
first turbo falls off, a second, larger turbo has already spooled up and 
begins boosting the engine to maintain a strong power curve throughout the 
rev. This is important in trailering situations where torque is needed at 
all points in the power band for a smooth, powerful feeling, and efficient 
driving experience. However as someone mentioned earlier, turbos are a 
double edged sword. Due to the way that the ecoboost engine is almost 
always subjected to boost, it is subjected to a lot more stress than a v8 
engine would be while doing a similar amount of work. For this reason, the 
ecoboost in particular is known to run extremely hot under continuous 
working conditions, and even break if subjected to a regular (I mean like 
over the years here) workload; ie pulling trailers every day. It is for 
this reason that heavy duty twin turbo diesel engines always carry a 
powerful inter-cooler to manage temperatures, which the ecoboost f-150 
notably lacks. At the end of the day, despite the technological achievement 
the ecoboost is, I would recommend a v8 to anyone who needs a long-lasting 
working truck.
comments.author: Zachary Strain

comments.text:
+Frank thebestestest A V6 ecoboost has better torque across the whole RPM 
range than a coyote V8, look it up. Turbocharged always beats naturally 
aspirated, there's plenty of 4 cylinders than have more power and torque 
than an N/A V8. Go back to the 1960s when what you're babbling about was 
actually somewhat true.
comments.author: deimosian

comments.text:

comments.author: Bill Lumbergh

comments.text:
+deimosian what? how much crack have you smoked before commenting? That is 
the exact opposite of the truth. Are you trolling lol?  The only 
turbocharged cars that make a wide peak torque are V8 turbocharged cars, 
and I was talking about V6s and under.  Go home idiot
comments.author: Bill Lumbergh

comments.text:
+Frank thebestestest You clearly don't know anything about turbocharged 
engines. They have much wider peak torque bands than naturally aspirated 
engines and are much more competent at towing. This is why no one uses a 
naturally aspirated diesel, since real towing is done with diesels and real 
towing benefits from a turbo or two. Please educate yourself or fuck off.
comments.author: deimosian

comments.text:
+Frank thebestestestI can confirm this. I had a 91 Dodge Daytona Shelby 
2.5L 4 cylinder with a Garrett T2 turbo. Got great mpg driving like a 
granny, but if I played in it mustang 5.0's got better mileage than me lol
comments.author: BMW Guy

comments.text:
+Michael Williams 24 mpg? are you really trying to make yourself look like 
a joke intentionally?  That is the maximum mpg possible, at highway 
cruising speeds, with the cruise control on, and absolutely no weight in it 
at all.  Put so much as a stack of cinderblocks in the back an you will see 
that mpg dip below 18, guaranteed. 

Do you even know how a turbocharger works, or even how it gives better fuel 
economy for that matter?  When you are driving in low rpm, it gives a 
bigger fire in the cylinder because of a higher concentration of air, 
requiring less fuel to keep it moving.  
When you floor it, or put strain on it from hauling weight, you burn 
through fuel at twice the rate as normal because in order to spool up and 
create boost it requires more fuel to do so.
Turbochargers are a double edged sword, drive conservatively and you will 
save gas but spool up the turbos to higher boost and you will eat through 
gas faster than the V8 would.

Class dismissed.
comments.author: Bill Lumbergh

comments.text:
+Michael Williams THAT is only more torque at a specific rpm, the powerband 
is much weaker on turbo V6s than V8s, did you not get that from what I 
posted? 

The ecoboost was never intended for people towing real loads or doing real 
work, they are for wannabee urban rednecks like yourself who want to 
overcompensate and look more "manly"

I have an '06 F-150 with the Triton V8, an "outdated" engine as you so 
stupidly put it, that can easily tow a 10,000 lb horse trailer.  Try that 
in your stupid V6 ecoboost and see what happens haha.

Go ahead, keep throwing out numbers when you have no idea what they really 
mean.  

You are so naive and know NOTHING about engines.  V8s are always preferred 
for towing because they give even power throughout the rpm range, therefore 
making towing much smoother and easier than a turbo V6 especially up hills. 
 The turbos only make power once you reach a certain rpm, otherwise it is 
just a weak V6.

They did side by side towing comparisons against Dodge and Chevy V8s and 
found that the turbo V6 performed much more poorly and slower, ESPECIALLY 
UP HILLS.  It does not matter what the numbers say, when it comes to towing 
you want an even powerband. 

Oh, and not to mention the fuel economy on the turbo V6s are much lower 
than they claim, and even had WORSE mpg than the V8s in some conditions.
comments.author: Bill Lumbergh

comments.text:
+Frank thebestestest ...The fuck?

2015 3.5 V6 F150 has 40 ft pounds more torque than the V8, could easily 
eclipse 500 ft pounds of torque at the crank with a tune, and is rated to 
tow more. The only time the V6 loses out the the V8 is a load that requires 
it to stay in boost...and that is recompensed when you hop on the highway, 
without a load, and turn 24MPG (vs the typical 18 with the V8). 

Hell, the 2.7 Ecoboost makes 30 foot pounds less than the V8, and will 
probably turn 28MPG. 


The Eco boost V6 is for fleet buyers that tow occasionally, and, well, 
generally intelligent people.

Because if you're HONESTLY considering that outdated, POS, V8 because you 
tow...go buy the Ram Eco diesel or a lightly used Duramax/Cummins/etc.
comments.author: Michael Williams

comments.text:
+Daniel Goodman they will for base models but do you really think american 
truck companies will ever stop selling big V8s? Never, the V8s are in too 
high demand for REAL work.  At the moment, he turbo V6s are horrible for 
torque and have overrated fuel economy.  The F150 ecoboost couldnt even tow 
a lawnmower without sucking up gas even more than the V8 would.
The turbo V6s are for urban rednecks, who tow more groceries on city roads 
than payloads.
